awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Developing a Theory for Function Optimization on Graphs Using Local Information
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to advance the frontiers of knowledge concerning efficient search on networked data. The investigators will devise new algorithms for optimizing a function defined over a graph. Such algorithms will be easily implementable, broadly applicable, and backed by mathematical theory. Some example application areas in which the work will be relevant include faster web retrieval and cybersecurity, where it is important to identify key individuals in a large web of interconnected data. The project will also support the educational goals of the investigators by training multiple graduate students working at the interface of theoretical and applied data science research.

The work conducted in this project will establish new connections between continuous and discrete optimization. The investigators will explore notions of smoothness and convexity that may be used to characterize the convergence properties of their proposed optimization algorithms; unlike optimization on graphs, optimization on continuous domains is backed by a mature theory that has been developed over several decades. Developing an analogous theory for discrete domains such as graphs poses many challenges, however -- in particular, it requires developing new notions of derivatives, Hessians, smoothness, or convexity, which have no obvious analogs. This work is divided into the following sub-projects, each with a distinct set of research objectives: (1) Develop and analyze iterative and local algorithms on graphs; (2) Find suitable notions of smoothness and convexity on graphs, and analyze their consequences. In addition, the algorithms will be implemented and evaluated on various real-world networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project were to develop a theory for function optimization on graphs and solve challenging problems at the intersection of graph theory and probability.  Another important component of this project was the training of graduate students by providing them hands-on experience with interdisciplinary research and exposure to both theoretical and empirical work.

The project consisted of three main thrusts:

1) Function optimization on graphs: We investigated functions on discrete graphs and ways to find their global optima using local algorithms. Our study revealed several challenges in posing such a problem correctly. Unlike Euclidean spaces, graphs do not have an inherent geometry (there are no axes, for instance), so local algorithms do not necessarily reveal any global information. Moreover, defining derivatives, smoothness, convexity, etc. for functions requires making specific choices that decide what aspects of these properties we need to preserve in discrete settings. The main insight of our investigations was that the function and the graph need to be studied together -- arbitrary pairs of graphs and functions are not optimizable using local algorithms.

2) Influence maximization problems on graphs:  Influence maximization is a well-known optimization problem on graphs, where one aims to find a small number of vertices that have the largest influence. This problem has applications in epidemiology and advertising. It is known to be computationally hard in general but algorithms that approximate the optimum value are known. In our work, we consider an adversarial setting (which generalizes the standard stochastic setting). Ours was the very first paper to pose this problem, and we established upper and lower bounds on the minimax regret in both undirected and directed networks. 


(3) Communication and Information on graphs: We investigated how fast information can spread on a graph when communication between nodes is restricted. We showed several surprising results that indicated information can spread very slowly when the vertices appear to be doing something optimal but can spread fast when the vertices use a simple protocol. We also studied optimal rates for hypothesis testing in certain graphs and conjectured the optimal rates in others. 

The most significant impact of this project has been through uncovering new directions for research. Optimization on graphs, adversarial influence maximization, and communication on graphs are novel problems introduced during this project that are intellectually stimulating to mathematicians, statisticians, and engineers.
